bibl.title: [Letter] 1833 Mar. 27 [to] J.M. King, Murfreesboro, Rutherford County, Tennessee / Hardy Moore
bibl.author: Moore, Hardy
bibl.note: This is a letter dated March 27, 1833 from Hardy Moore to his cousin James Moore King in Murfreesboro, Tennessee. Moore tells King that he has purchased a farm in the south.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

address.addrLine: Ja M King Murfreesborough Rutherford Cty Tenn

div1.p: I received yours of 8th of Feb. I answer it with pleasure but I presume you have all most despared of hearing from me I have just got home from the lower country a few days since Col King and my self have purchased a farm in the south and have sent our negroes down in fort and I had been down to arrange affairs you wish to know whether Dr Moore has returned he has returned from Levington I wrote him while at Lexington to come by your house but he made such a short stay there that he did not receive my letter before he left he would have come by you also wish to know whether I succeded in getting to carry the electrieal vote to washington I declined holding a pole for the appointment as I was late getting to Tuskaloosa

It is with sincere repent that that I learned the death of your son Washington Lafayette and I sympathise with you for the loss but Cousin this is a matter on reflection that there is no alternative for and we should compare our selves are much as possible uncle Henry is in very bad health the balance of our friends are all well also at Tuskaloosa I have a fine family in the south but ove for it but think I shall pay for it very easy
div1.closer: present my respects to aunt Cousin Martha and the children and all my enquiring friends yours in sincerityHardy H Moore write me soon
